title: Dores Beach Walking Route

images.title: Anne Burgess / Dores Beach and Tor Point
images.caption: Dores Beach and Tor Point. The pebble beach in a bay near the foot of Loch Ness.

images.title: Alasdair MacNeill / The colours of nature
images.caption: The colours of nature I liked this picture due to the vivid yellow of the whin clashing with the blues and greens of the Loch and surrounding mountains.

images.title: John Hedger / Dores beach from south of Dores
images.caption: Dores beach from south. Taken in the spring.

images.title: Anne Burgess / Dores
images.caption: Almost horizontal light from the setting sun gives a slightly unreal look to the village of Dores.

images.title: John Hedger / Torr Point
images.caption: Torr Point. Taken from the village on a snowy day in March.

images.title: Colin Smith / Dores Inn
images.caption: Dores Inn. Superb historic village inn and restaurant on the shores of Loch Ness.

images.title: Alasdair MacNeill / Dores Bay
images.caption: The view across Dores Bay to Tor Point. The Rockness music festival is held on the fields slightly to the right of this photograph.

images.title: Colin Smith / Dores Beach
images.caption: At the head of Strath Dores, heading alongside a shingly Loch Ness beach towards wooded Tor Point.

description: This walk visits the lovely Dores Beach and Tor Point on the north eastern shores of the famous Loch Ness. You can start your walk from the parking area at the beach. From here you can pick up the shoreline and follow it west along the beach to Tor Point. It's just over a mile walk there and back, so should take around 30 minutes. Along the way there's excellent views over Dores Bay to the surrounding hills. You can extend the walk by continuing north through the woodland around Tor Point to visit Aldourie Castle.
